comments.commentBody: His path to the White House continues to narrow. He flip-flopped on the egregious Blunt Amendment, today. He's now supporting it. He was "resolute" in opposing the amendment for ONE HOUR. He lacks the character to be President. It's that simple.
Assad family is mass killers dad Hafez killed hundred of thousands in his 40 years uncle Refaat killed 50 thousands in Hama 1982 and junior now is catching up fast killing 300 per day
Little Bashar is a cowered he continues to kill because of that little corrupt dictator sitting in Moscow
I suppose if you cannot call him a strong "leader", the next best thing is to call him a "grown up".

I am sure there must be a better way to cultivate gender equity without encouraging gender confusion in children. Clear gender role becomes evident even when you leave toddler girls and boys to play by themselves. Even without the larger societal input, this will continue to be reinforced throughout childhood by each group's dynamics. Much of the rejection of even basic gender roles is nothing more than the feminist ego applying untested and unscientific experimentation with their children. The cinderella fantasies we intentionally deny our young girls return among the so call feminists in later years in the sphere of fashion, makeup and tendency to romantic novels,  and movies and human-side magazines. Still the girls are doing okay. College enrollment in undergrad and grad school are up,the  proportion of women in the workforce is rising.This tells a Let the girls be girls and the boys be boys.

Why stop at $250,000? Every worker should pay on all income, and the very wealthy will get it back when they reach 66 or 67, like the rest of us. And they'll get a greater amount than you or I because the payment is based on their earnings. Hmmm ... maybe that's the part that needs to be re-thought.

@Martin -- all public school teachers can retire with full benefits (88% of final pay, which is huge) after 30 years....for most of them, this is age 52. Not 65!

If a teacher choses to stay on and teach more years, they get huge additional retirement pay. They also are exempt from SS, because their pensions are so lux.

If they wish to retire earlier, they can do so as early as 46, after 25 years of work, though their pension payout is slightly smaller.

This is mostly true for all public employees -- some police and firemen can retire after TWENTY years.

It is unfair to compare these spoiled petulant public grifters with hardworking miners, taxi drivers, waitresses and other workers who really put in grueling hours for little pay and benefits.

65 was fine and reasonable; raising that age was unfair. I must wait an extra year and half now to collect SS or face significant cuts in my benefit.

Anyone who thinks you can "just keep working a blue collar job" at age 67 is almost certainly young and rich and clueless -- they do not understand that people have health problems, arthritis, they are getting older and tired.

Furthermore, every old person forced to work longer is keeping a job that could go to a YOUNG unemployed person with a family!!!! The supply of jobs is NOT unlimited, it is finite.

Walter, I would respectfully point out that your sample is way too small to draw general conclusions. Lifestyles have certainly changed, but it all depends on the person, genetics, and other factors. Certain occupations have ergonomic injury practically built into them, regardless of lifestyle. Repetitive motion does its damage over time and some are more prone than others to things like arthritis.

We tend to romanticize the life of the pre-industrial farmer. It was a very hard life and most welcomed the technological advances that made life easier. The poor everywhere eat “better” (short of starvation) than those with access to excess calories, but they don’t necessarily live longer in general due to lack of access to health care.

You should never raise taxes on the rich but its OK to raise the retirement age of working class people.

This is more classist thinking. As one commenter wrote, try being a police officer or firefighter at 65. How about public school teachers? Coal miners?
Taxi drivers?

I think people should retire as early as possible so as to enjoy life with a little stress as possible. 65 seems just fine to me. The GOP argues that since people are living longer we should raise the retirement age. I think that people living longer is something to celebrate because that means they can enjoy their golden years longer free to do whatever they please. Should people work until they drop like farm animals, or work to an age where they are less capable of enjoying retirement?

Of course if you are a blowhard politician or an investment banker who sits on their keister all day, working well into the 70's is just fine because they sit most of th time and their jobs are not physically demanding.

This is but another indication of their lack of empathy for and disregard of the working class and ordinary Americans.

What's the difference retiring at 65 0r 67 or 68? A big difference! It's two or three less years of living without the stress of ordering life based upon another person's schedule. It's less time to develop new aspects of one's personality. It's less time to reflect upon ones life, make better sense of it and actually prepare to our final exit.

Raise the cap to $250,000!

Unfortunately we aren't going to give anything up.  So we've better try to learn to accept it, sad as it is.  But keep this is mind, everything in nature has an expiration date, you, me, trees and even this earth and solar system.  It is all going to come to an end, one way or another, soon or later.  What we are doing is just speeding things up.  I'm glad I don't have any children.

Who can afford a real house on $12.00 an hour?  High winds are happening all over the country.  Look at the "red" danger zone for potential tornadoes that is in effect till Friday, it covers five or six states.
The North Korean nuke program is Bush's fault not the Dear Leaders!

The DPRK was busily violating the deal even before Pres. Clinton left office.

--
By 2000, US intelligence had begun to detect North Korean attempts to procure equipment and materials that could be used in a centrifuge programme. However, the quantities were small, suggesting a research and development effort, and technical opinion was divided on whether the items were intended for use in centrifuges or for other purposes, such as in missiles. Nonetheless, there was sufficient concern that, in March 2000, US President Clinton waived a legislative certification that required him to certify that ‘North Korea is not seeking to develop or acquire the capability to enrich uranium’. In 2001, a source – said to be a North Korean defector – reported that North Korea had been pursuing a centrifuge enrichment programme for several years, although the location of the production plant and related facilities were apparently not identified.13 Moreover, North Korea reportedly began seeking large quantities of materials and components that were uniquely associated with centrifuge production, such as high-strength aluminium tubes of specific dimensions and equipment suitable for uranium feed-and-withdrawal systems.
--
http://www.iiss.org/publications/strategic-dossiers/north-korean-dossier...

But the announcement seemed to signal that North Korea’s new leader, Kim Jong-un, is at least willing to consider a return to negotiations and to engage with the United States, which pledged in exchange to ship tons of food aid to the isolated, impoverished nation.

This is pure crap, he is doing the same thing his "father" did and will probably be just as successful at scamming the USA, "the Idiots of the west" who will ship hims food, which will be sent to his military, ONLY, and then renege and do it all over again. If Oblamo falls for this it will only prove what the rest of the world takes as obvious, he is an idiot.

The DPRK is once again procuring materials in an ongoing massive effort for full scale operations, and the rest of the world knows it, apparently America does not.

During the latter months of the Clinton Administration, Madeline Albright had a similar deal set up with Kim-Jong-il. The only difference was that the trade was for fuel oil. She briefed the Bush Administration which went about beating plowshares into swords and then rattling them. It has taken ten years to get back to where we were.

My congratulations to the people who managed to get back to where we were, only now we have a belligerent Congress. I hope they can whip up enough brainpower to support Secretary Clinton.
The peach farm where I get peaches in the fall lost their entire crop due to a late season frost which happened last March and destroyed the blossoms.  Yikes.

It is not going to matter. With China and Russia, using more and more energy, India, etc., we are heading to an abrupt end. It seemed that only yesterday we were using 10 million barrels of oil a DAY, now we are up to 20 million barrels and if we could get a barrel for $70 we'd use even more. Remember this, the United States used to be the world's biggest polluter, now we are running neck and neck with China.

Maybe if we had free, subsidized, public transportation we might be able to reduce that number, but only by a little bit.

wow Bataille seems to be in French bashing mood but have lost some restraint

Hey buddy, we did not invade Alaska (for a change this time around we didn't). On March 30, 1867, Secretary of State William H. Seward agreed to purchase Alaska from Russia for $7.2 million. At the time, critics thought Seward was crazy and called the deal "Seward's folly." Seward was laughed at for his willingness to spend so much on "Seward's icebox" and Andrew Johnson's "polar bear garden." In contrast, the Falklands were inhabited by Argentinians when the Brits invaded them and killed their population. Of course, it follows that the inhabitants now wish to be Brits.C'mon, do you really believe that England would be at all interested in those folks' fate if there was no oil or fishery in the region?

The history of the islands seems more complex than you describe. France was the first country to establish control in the Falkland (Malvinas) Islands, with the foundation of Port Saint Louis in 1764. The Islands were named after the Breton port of St. Malo as the Îles Malouines, (the French name for the islands). In 1766, France agreed to leave the islands to Spain, with Spain reimbursing France for the cost of the settlement. Spain claimed the Islands under provisions in the Treaty of Tordesillas which settled the limits of the Spanish Empire in the Americas.  The Spanish took control of Port Saint Louis and renamed it Puerto Soledad in 1767 and regained control of the Islands. In fact, Spain and Great Britain came close to war over the issue, but instead, concluded a treaty on 22 January 1771, allowing the British to return to Port Egmont with neither side relinquishing sovereignty claims. The British returned in 1771 but for economic reasons decided to leave the islands in 1774 leaving Spain in full de facto control. As Argentina declared independence from Spain, the islands were ruled from Buenos Aires as part of the Viceroyalty of the River Plate till they were again invaded by Great Britain. May be France, Argentina, Spain and England should get a quarter island each, and cooperate on fishery and exploitation of resources.
The funding method of public education is clearly a mess, but there are plenty of well educated, well informed, progressive thinking folks in Ohio...thank you very much.

I'm originally from Ohio and if recent elections there are any indication the voters of the Buckeye State will go for the most vile candidate possible attempting to shoot themselves in the foot. The public education system in Ohio is laughable and under-funded as school levees are consistently defeated by a short-sighted, stingy electorate. It's one of the major reasons I moved from there 20 years ago.

Santorum makes it up as he goes along. He absolutely lies and has no qualms about it. Take N. Dakota, he spouts that if only there was more drilling, the price of oil would go down, but it's the bad, evil EPA that prevents drilling. Well, from what I've read N. Dakota is drilling away. This man has no shame!

This was not bullying, but abuse. Bullying is peer-to-peer; abuse is superior-to-subordinate. Bullying is not illegal, which is one of the reasons it's such a huge problem. Abuse is illegal, though perhaps not in earlier days. The trauma and memories, however, are often the same.
These definitions are interesting, but where then does domestic violence by minors against parents fall in this taxonomy?

@ Barbara

It is illegal in many cases. The charge is, Disorderly Conduct. Certain Ad Hominems cross the line.

Though I'm certainly not in her generation, I really admire Lady Gaga and the foundation which she has established. I was fortunate not to be bullied in high school, and tried to keep out of the way of such people. Bullying can take strange forms. Once in class in my Catholic high school, one of the students had thrown a huge spitball which stuck to the black board. The teacher, a priest, became enraged and asked the boy to come forward, where he held one of his arms and repeatedly kicked him on his buttocks.

The boy was crying hard, he was a popular and well liked boy. The other boys in the class were stunned, we didn't know what to do. The boy yelled to the priest that he was going to the principal. When the boy returned, he told the priest that the principal, a kindly priest, wanted to see him immediately.

After some time, the abusive priest came back and contritely said he was very sorry for what he had done, that it was wrong, and apologized to the boy. I know I never trusted this priest after that incident and imagine it is seared into the memory of that student forever. Bullying seems to come in all shapes and sizes.

(btw, I'm fairly liberal and) I fail to see the racism in this. The artistry is nice.

If someone looking at the cover sees a desirable white women emerging through a few undesirable black women, then that person is arguably racist. If someone sees the color of the women's skin being used to create a visually striking contrast in color, then there is no evidence of racism in that person.

If there is any racisim in this particular case, it is in the eye of the beholder. Because there is a legitamate non-racist purpose for the use of the different skin colors, it is impossible to know whether the artists' were motivated by racist ideas.

I suspect that the type of people who create magazine covers are artisticly inclined and truly enjoy playing with color in interesting ways (which is how I viewed the cover when I first saw it). I see no reason to think there was any racist intent behind it.

As far as the use of the word "shadows," if you tell an artist to symobolize someone stepping out of shadows, they will not think of the shadows as some inferior or undesirable place. Artists love shadows, and many would think of them in a positive way. It would make sense to place beautiful women as a shadow without any negative connotation.
A democratic Senator will change nothing.
An itchy nose is no big deal. I wouldn't lose any sleep over it.

The DHubby is into his 20th year on a c-pap, and the newer models are much quieter and the mask designs much better.  In the early days, I found it rather like sleeping with Darth Vader (HISS-click, HISS-click) and I admit I still prefer to be the first to fall asleep...  It made a huge difference in how rested he feels after nap or night-long sleep; I hope it does the same for you!

I hope the CPAP does well for you, RE....although it's a little scary to think of how much energy you'll have well-rested! ;)

(wow)

I wonder why 64a was not clued "shore bird"?

I liked this puzzle a lot. Best thing about it was for whatever reason, I changed no letters or answers, waiting to fill stuff in until I was reasonably sure of what went where That doesn't happen too often, and my head is a lil swelled right now. 19 minutes.

Actually that may be due to it being my first night with a CPAP mask on my mouth and nose. So far, only really bad things are coughing, which doesn't seem to work too well, and scratching an itch say on my nose, which makes the machine pump more and more air until I seal the mask on again. Oh well, maybe it'll help my apnea ...
